name: Service Mesh Interface specification
description:
Service Mesh Interface (SMI) is a widely-adopted open specification that helps ensure interoperability of service meshes, a popular abstraction layer in the Kubernetes ecosystem. 

SMI provides a standard interface for applications that connect to a service mesh and defines the basic features for common use cases. This specification covers mesh capabilities such traffic policy (for identity and transport encryption), traffic telemetry (to measure error rate and latency), and traffic management (allowing traffic to be shifted between services). SMI is also flexible enough to support new service mesh capabilities over time as the ecosystem evolves.
description_good_justification:
https://smi-spec.io says: 
"What SMI covers
Service Mesh Interface is a specification that covers the most common service mesh capabilities:

Traffic policy – apply policies like identity and transport encryption across services
Traffic telemetry – capture key metrics like error rate and latency between services
Traffic management – shift traffic between different services"
interact_justification: The project website links to GitHub, where all these items are available: https://github.com/servicemeshinterface/smi-spec
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/servicemeshinterface/smi-spec/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: https://github.com/servicemeshinterface/smi-spec/blob/master/README.md As SMI is a spec, not code, the README contains information about the project.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/servicemeshinterface/smi-spec/blob/master/LICENSE>.

name: Crypto++
description: Free C++ class library of cryptographic schemes
license: Public Domain or Boost Software License v1 (BSL-1.0)
description_good_justification: "Free C++ class library of cryptographic schemes", https://cryptopp.com
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/License.txt.
floss_license_justification: Public Domain or Boost Software License v1 (BSL-1.0), https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/License.txt.
floss_license_osi_justification: Public Domain or Boost Software License v1 (BSL-1.0), https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/License.txt.
documentation_basics_justification: Link to Manual on homepage, https://www.cryptopp.com/docs/ref/. Link to wiki with code examples on homepage, https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/.
documentation_interface_justification: Link to Manual on homepage, https://www.cryptopp.com/docs/ref/.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Crypto++ does not use dead-end branches. It pollutes the Git log history. Instead testing forks are used and proposals are discussed.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: The README is the primary human readable document. https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/Readme.txt. Each release has its own HTML page. For example, https://github.com/weidai11/website.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Each release has its own HTML page that highlights CVEs and major problems that were corrected. For example, from https://github.com/weidai11/website/blob/master/release565.html: "Crypto++ 5.6.5 was released on October 11, 2016. The 5.6.5 release was mostly a maintenance release. The release included two CVE fixes." Then, the CVE details are provided.
report_responses_justification: Typically the projects response time is less than a day. https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/issues.
enhancement_responses_justification: Typically the projects response time is less than a day. https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/issues.
report_archive_justification: GitHub allows searching of past and closed reports. https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/issues.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: We do not support private vulnerabilities. As soon as we get a private report we forward it to the mailing list at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/cryptopp-users.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Typically the projects response time is less than a day.
build_justification: Non-trivial build file in repository: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/GNUmakefile>. The project also supplies Autotools <https://github.com/noloader/cryptopp-autotools>, CMake <https://github.com/noloader/cryptopp-cmake> and Visual Studio project files for those who wish to use them.
build_common_tools_justification: Non-trivial build file in repository: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/GNUmakefile>. The project also supplies Autotools, CMake and Visual Studio project files for those who wish to use them.
build_floss_tools_justification: The project only requires GNU Make. CD into the project directory and run 'make -j 4'. It really is as easy as that. The project also supplies Autotools, CMake and Visual Studio project files for those who wish to use them.
test_justification: Linux and OS X builds using Travis CI: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.travis.yml>. FreeBSD builds using Cirrus CI: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.cirrus.yml>. Android and iOS builds using Travis CI: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.travis.yml>. Windows builds using AppVeyor: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.appveyor.yml>.
test_invocation_justification: 'make test' and 'make check' work for me. It follows the GNU Coding Standards.
test_most_justification: Our test suite is comprised of about 13 source files and covers about 80% of the library.
test_policy_justification: Crypto++ is a library of cryptographic schemes. Our governance requires test coverage for new algorithms and protocols. At minimum, a new algorithm will include Known Answer Tests (KATs). Public Key algorithms will include Pairwise Consistency Tests.
tests_are_added_justification: Crypto++ is a library of cryptographic schemes. Our governance requires test coverage for new algorithms and protocols. At minimum, a new algorithm will include Known Answer Tests (KATs). Public Key algorithms will include Pairwise Consistency Tests.
tests_documented_added_justification:
Our governance requires new algorithms have both documentation on the wiki and test cases. We don't add new algorithms without test cases. It is too dangerous.

It looks like we need to add a wiki page on this topic. I thought we had one, but I cannot find it.
warnings_justification: Testing includes -Wall -Wextra with GCC and Clang. On Windows, testing include /W4. We also have a test script from hell that builds the project in 50-100 permutations (depending on the platform and features available). The tests from hell include 6 different builds to tease warnings. Also see <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/TestScripts/cryptest.sh>.
warnings_fixed_justification: Our governance requires us to clear warnings under reasonable flags. To date our "reasonable flags" includes -Wall -Wextra. Otherwise, we get mailing list messages and bug reports for them.
warnings_strict_justification: Testing includes -Werror when using GCC and Clang.
know_secure_design_justification:
The development team includes one Security Architect from US Financial and US DoD. The other maintainers have CVs that includes years of cryptography and security experience.

The library has also been FIPS 140-2 validated by the US government. The FIPS 140-2 validation includes a SP800-56a audit for processes and procedures.
know_common_errors_justification:
The development team includes includes members of OWASP. The other maintainers have CVs that includes years of cryptography and security experience.

The library has also been FIPS 140-2 validated by the US government. The FIPS 140-2 validation includes a SP800-56a audit for processes and procedures.
crypto_published_justification: The library includes well known algorithms, like AES; and lesser known algorithms, like RC6, MARS and Twofish.
crypto_call_justification: The project is a cryptographic library.
crypto_floss_justification: The project is a cryptographic library.
crypto_keylength_justification: When available, the project implements 256-bits of security and above. 256-bits of security exceeds the US government's recommendations on key sizes. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Security_Level>.
crypto_working_justification:
The project is a cryptographic library. The project includes weak and wounded ciphers for historical reasons and research purposes.

However, to use a weak or wounded cipher, a user must build the library with -DCRYPTOPP_ENABLE_NAMESPACE_WEAK. The setting is off-by-default. Then, a user can use a weak or wounded cipher within the Weak:: namespace. I.e., Weak::MD2, Weak::MD5, etc.
crypto_pfs_justification: The project includes ephemeral key exchanges, like DHE and ECDHE.
crypto_password_storage_justification: The library itself does not store secrets, like private keys, shared secrets or passwords. Users may build applications that do so, but the library does not.
crypto_random_justification: The library includes approved software generators like NIST DBRG from SP800-90. The library also includes hardware-based PRNGS, like Padlock, RDRAND, RDSEED and DARN. DARN is the RDRAND equivalent on PowerPC.
delivery_mitm_justification: The project signs its release; see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Signing>. The project also uses a trusted distribution channel for downloads using TLS and a Let's Encrypt certificate.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The project's signing algorithm for release tarballs is SHA-256.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: The project typically responds to bugs within one day. Some patches take longer, but the patches are made available as soon as it is ready (i.e., passes testing).
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: The project typically responds to bugs within one day. Some patches take longer, but the patches are made available as soon as it is ready (i.e., passes testing).
static_analysis_justification: The project uses Coverity Scan on Linux and OS X. The project uses Visual Studio Enterprise Analysis on Windows. Finally, the project uses the Looks Good To Me continuous security analysis. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Coverity_Scan> and <https://lgtm.com>.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The project uses Coverity Scan on Linux and OS X. The project uses Visual Studio Enterprise Analysis on Windows. Finally, the project uses the Looks Good To Me continuous security analysis. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Coverity_Scan> and <https://lgtm.com>.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: The project typically responds to analysis findings within a hour when run manually, or within a day when reported by a user.
static_analysis_often_justification:
Source code analysis is limited to weekly testing due to limits Synopsis places on the free Security Scan service. I.e., the project is only allowed 12 scans a week. We need to save the extra scans for reproducers and retesting.

Looks Good To Me continuous security analysis is unlimited, but it is not as good as Coverity.
dynamic_analysis_justification:
The project uses Valgrind and Sanitizers to test for runtime violations. Valgrind detects memory and thread problems. Santiziers include Asan, Msan and UBsan.

The projects self tests also "fuzz" certain interfaces attempting to crash the test suite. The fuzzing occurs under Valgrind, Asan and Msan.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification:
The project uses Valgrind and Sanitizers to test for runtime violations. Valgrind detects memory and thread problems. Santiziers include Asan, Msan and UBsan.

The projects self tests also "fuzz" certain interfaces attempting to crash the test suite. The fuzzing occurs under Valgrind, Asan and Msan.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi:
Debug builds of the project includes asserts to aide the developer in finding mistakes.

Release builds are built with -DNDEBUG and will NEVER asset. The library will validate the parameters and/or state and throw an exception on failure. Anywhere there is an 'if' statement to validate state includes an assert. Anywhere there is an assert to validate state includes an 'if' statement that throws. They are matched set like bookends.

The Crypto++ library never asserts in production for five reasons. First, it is the application's authors decision to crash their app. The library does not make policy decisions for the application author.

Second, some platforms, like Apple iOS, forbid applications from crashing because it degrades the UI experience. In this case, the App Store has set the policy for the application author. The library will not cause an author's app to be rejected from an App Store.

Third, the library handles sensitive information like private keys, shared secrets and passwords. When an assert fires a core file could be written that includes the sensitive information. That means the sensitive information has been egressed outside the application's security boundary. Folks with access to the mobile device, desktop computer or a computer paired/sync'd with the mobile device will be able to recover the secrets from the filesystem.

Fourth, the core file, if present, may be shipped to an Error Reporting Service. Now Apple, Google, Fedora, Red Hat, Ubuntu or Microsoft have the user's private keys, shared secrets and passwords. Then the information is then passed onto the developer who has the user's private keys, shared secrets and passwords, too.

Fifth, asserts destroy most of Confidentiality-Availability-Integrity (CIA). When an assert crashes a program, it (1) may preserve data Integrity at the expense of (2) Confidentiality of the data and (3) Availability of the program or server. If an author wishes to preserve Integrity, he/she/it merely needs to return false in the offending function or call exit(1) without the loss of Confidentiality or Availability.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: The project typically responds to analysis findings within a hour when run manually, or within a day when reported by a user.
general_comments: Crypto++ is one of the oldest projects on the web. It was started by Wei Dai in 1992 and the first public release was 1994. Crypto++ was one of the targets of RSA Data Security Inc (RSA DSI) takedowns due to use of RSA while it was still patented. In June 2015 Wei Dai turned the library over to the community for maintenance.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: When available, the project uses 128-bits of security by default. 128-bits of security is the US government's recommendation nowadays.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Linux and OS X builds using Travis CI: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.travis.yml>. FreeBSD builds using Cirrus CI: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.cirrus.yml>. Android and iOS builds using Travis CI: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.travis.yml>. Windows builds using AppVeyor: <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/.appveyor.yml>.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests. We also have traditional mailing lists at https://www.cryptopp.com/#lists.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The library does not publish private keys, shared secrets or passwords. Or not that we know of.
english_justification: Link to Manual on homepage, https://www.cryptopp.com/docs/ref/. Link to wiki with code examples on homepage, https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/.
hardening_justification: The project uses hardened toolchain settings when available, like -fexceptions, -fplugin=annobin, -fstack-clash-protection, -fstack-protector-strong (or -fstack-protector), -grecord-gcc-switches, -mcet -fcf-protection, -Werror=format-security, -Werror=implicit-function-declaration, -fPIC and -pie for ASLR, -Wa,--noexecstack, -Wl,-z,relro, -Wl,-z,now and -Wl,-z,defs.
crypto_used_network_justification: The library does not provide protocols like SSH or TLS.
crypto_tls12_justification: The library does not provide protocols like SSH or TLS.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific:
The library does not provide protocols like SSH or TLS.

The library does provide a X.509 certificate class that can be used to read and verify certificates and certificate chains. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/X509Certificate>.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: The library does not provide protocols like SSH or TLS.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Absolutely. The project follows GNU Coding Standards by default. 'make install' and 'make uninstall' are supported in the makefile.
implementation_languages: C++, Assembly, GNU Makefile, Visual Studio project files, NMake makefile
dco_justification:
The library does not have a process in place to handle paperwork like Developer Certificate of Origin (DCO).

The library does require contributors to place their contributions in Public Domain to avoid legal issues. It is a precondition to accepting a contribution. But it is not the same as "legal authority to make contributions [sic]". Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Category:Patch>.
governance_justification: The project's governance is detailed in several places. In particular <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Process> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Signing>. We should probably create a PDF with the relevant information in one place.
code_of_conduct_justification: Do we really need to restate the Golden Rule?
roles_responsibilities_justification: The project's key players and their roles are detailed in several places. In particular <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Process> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Signing>. We should probably create a PDF with the relevant information in one place.
access_continuity_justification: The project's key players and their roles are detailed in several places. In fact four different key members were selected from different regions of the world to ensure continuity. In particular <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Process> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Signing>. We should probably create a PDF with the relevant information in one place.
bus_factor_justification: The project's key players and their roles are detailed in several places. In fact four different key members were selected from different regions of the world to ensure continuity. In particular <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Process> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Signing>. We should probably create a PDF with the relevant information in one place.
documentation_roadmap_justification: The project includes a Roadmap and Release Process. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Roadmap> and >https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Process>
documentation_architecture_justification: Documentation is provided in the Manual and the Wiki. The manual is Doxygen-based and brief and focuses on API. The wiki is verbose with lost of code examples and provides greater details. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/docs/ref/> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki>.
documentation_security_justification: Documentation is provided in the Manual and the Wiki. The manual is Doxygen-based and brief and focuses on API. The wiki is verbose with lost of code examples and provides greater details. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/docs/ref/> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki>.
documentation_quick_start_justification:
The quick Start guide is provided in Install.txt, which is similar to INSTALL. Also see <https://github.com/weidai11/cryptopp/blob/master/Install.txt>.

Documentation is provided in the Manual and the Wiki. The manual is Doxygen-based and brief and focuses on API. The wiki is verbose with lost of code examples and provides greater details. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/docs/ref/> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki>.
documentation_current_justification: Documentation is provided in the Manual and the Wiki. The manual is Doxygen-based and brief and focuses on API. The manual is frequently updated. The wiki is verbose and provides greater details. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/docs/ref/> and <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki>.
documentation_achievements_justification: Ugh, we need to update the site's HTML and cutover to markdown (*.md) for this.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Ugh, we are missing text alternatives for those using screen readers.
internationalization_justification: The library uses 7-bit ASCII clean for source code. The website uses UTF-8 encoding for web pages. The wiki uses UTF-8 encoding for web pages.
sites_password_security_justification:
The website is hosted on a CentOS 7 VM. Access is granted through SSH using public key only.

The source code is hosted on GitHub. Our governance requires code signing so nearly all commits are signed.

The wiki accounts are by request only. Once granted Mediawiki hashes the password using SHA-512.
maintenance_or_update_justification:
The library provides past releases back to Crypto++ 2.0 dated January 1998. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/downloads.html>.

Being a library there is little need for upgrade paths. When needed for backwards compatibility, the library provides a class with the older behavior. For example, when a particular software-based PRNG was changed, a new class with the old behavior was added due to user requests. Also see the "OldRandomPool" class at <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/RandomNumberGenerator#Old_RandomPool>.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: The library gives credit where credit is due. Also see release notes like <https://www.cryptopp.com/release600.html>.
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: The process for responding to bugs in general and security bugs in particular can be found at <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Bug_Report#Security_Bugs>.
coding_standards_justification:
Ugh, we fail...

On the good side, lack of coding standards removes a lot of barriers for patches. We don't reject contributions items like space vs tab,  how to comment, end-of-line conversions, etc. We accpet the patch and fix it according to our [internal] standards.
coding_standards_enforced_justification:
Ugh, we fail...

On the good side, lack of coding standards removes a lot of barriers for patches. We don't reject contributions items like space vs tab,  how to comment, end-of-line conversions, etc. We accpet the patch and fix it according to our [internal] standards.
build_standard_variables_justification: Absolutely. The project follows GNU Coding Standards by default. The user always has the final say in compilers and flags.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Absolutely. The project follows GNU Coding Standards by default. The project adds debug information in default builds.
build_non_recursive_justification: Absolutely. The project does not use recursive directories, so there is no recursive make.
build_repeatable_justification: Absolutely. The project attempts to obtain a reproducible builds.
installation_standard_variables_justific: Absolutely. The project follows GNU Coding Standards by default. Users are allowed to override default choices.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Absolutely. The project follows GNU Coding Standards by default. We also work hard to minimize dependencies. The only thing needed to setup an environment is GNU make 3.80 or higher and a working C++ compiler that supports RTTI and exceptions.
external_dependencies_justification:
The prject maintains three external projects. The three external projects allow users to use a different build system (other then GNU Make). The wiki pages for the projects:

* <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Autotools>
* <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/CMake>
* <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Android.mk>

And the corresponding GitHub repos:

* <https://github.com/noloader/cryptopp-autotools>
* <https://github.com/noloader/cryptopp-cmake>
* <https://github.com/noloader/cryptopp-android>
dependency_monitoring_justification:
While we provide external projects, they are only project build files for Autotools, Cmake and Android.

Whenever a new release of the library occurs, we package a new release of the build systems.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: While we provide external projects, they are only project build files for Autotools, Cmake and Android.
interfaces_current_justification: Absolutely. We remove deprecated APIs, or only provide them as needed for older/ancient platforms. On modern platforms the project uses modern system calls.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Absolutely. The project uses Travis, Cirrus and AppVeyor for CI. Results are sent to the [public] cryptopp-build mailing list at <https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/cryptopp-build>.
regression_tests_added50_justification: Our governance requires each bug and mailing list question has a postmortem examination. We try to determine why the instance problem (bug or question) happened. We then take action to fix future problems of the same class. We also add a specific test case in the case of a bug. We usually add documentation in response to a user question if it is missing. We consider lack of documentation bugs, too.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: The project uses Gcov, but it is not automated (yet).
test_policy_mandated_justification: Our governance requires new algorithms have both documentation on the wiki and test cases. We don't add new algorithms without test cases. It is too dangerous.
implement_secure_design_justification:
The project complies with FIPS 140-2 software requirements and attempts to use "secure by default" settings. For example, the library's assert is "off by default" because asserts are so dangerous. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Assertions>.

Note that the library only complies with FIPS 140-2. It is not longer validated (it used to be validated, but the validation was sunsetted by NIST).
input_validation_justification: The project does not handle untrusted user inputs. The applications that user the library may do so.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The Crypto++ library has an abundance of crypto agility :)
crypto_credential_agility_justification:
The library itself does not handle sensitive information per se.

The calling application will handle the sensitive information, and may use the library to encrypt it and store it where the user wants.
signed_releases_justification: The project signs releases with GnuPG using RSA-4096 keys and SHA-256 digests. Also see <https://www.cryptopp.com/wiki/Release_Signing>.
version_tags_signed_justification: Hmmm.... I don't know how to sign a tag.
assurance_case_justification: Ugh, the project lacks threat models, attack trees and compensating controls.
